Portal is such a tight, masterfully made little game. Its playtime may be brief, but every second is utilized with great efficiency. The game’s core mechanics are brilliantly conveyed, and puzzles are satisfying to solve. However, the game’s length does make it feel like certain mechanics are underutilized, as some are mostly dropped in the final act, while the Turrets feel just a bit out of place, especially given that their gunfire doesn’t meaningfully interact with other elements. And some veteran Portal players might find the start to be a bit slow, especially as you are restricted to producing only one portal yourself.
	The game excels in its environmental storytelling. The Aperture test areas start pristine and orderly, but disarray progressively creeps in. Numerous clues make it clear not everything’s as it seems. The puzzle design supports this as solutions seem to become more haphazard (in a good way) in the game’s final stretch, less “by design” in the context of the diegetic world. Puzzle layouts are also more cramped, supporting this sense that you’re not exploring the world as intended. The narrative itself is simple, but the execution makes it fully compelling.
	Visually, the game is intuitive in communicating important information to the player. It clearly conveys which surfaces allow for portals. Plus, the environment has subtle clues to put the player on the right track, such as the glow of a puzzle element onto an opposite wall, or scorch marks on the path of a High Energy Pellet.
The whole journey is buoyed by GLaDOS, a magnificent villain both legitimately threatening and amusing, thanks to her brilliant dialogue. Ellen McLain’s performance is pitch-perfect, with an excellent range and dynamic inflection to match the warping state of GLaDOS’ state of mind. You’ll hear her voice all throughout the short adventure, so McLain’s performance needed to deliver, and the result is one of gaming’s most compelling villains ever. Additionally, GLaDOS’ reveal at the game’s finale is truly a thing of wonder, with a physical form befitting such a malicious and sadistic AI. However, gameplay-wise, this encounter is a bit mundane, requiring only some simple maneuvers and puzzle unbefitting to the final conflict.
Perhaps the most striking difference in Portal from its more ambitious sequel is how bleak the game is, in a good way. The humor is dry and understated, while the story similarly sterile in contrast to the added cinematics of Portal 2. It ensures Portal is not rendered obsolete by its sequel.

Finally, I got a chance to play Portal, and all I can say is that it's amazing! The puzzles are challenging to a fair degree and it feels rewarding when you find the solution. What really takes the CAKE though, is the dark sense of humor present in this game, along with the overall mystery that keeps showing up in every level. This is phenomenal, and now I can understand why it's regarded as one of the best games.

It's a  great game.
